content: If TTT is a monad on a category CCC, then the monadic forgetful functor CT→CC^T \to CCT→C creates colimits that are preserved by TTT and T2T^2T2. This is Proposition 4.3.2 in Borceux's Handbook of Categorical Algebra 2. Is there an example that shows preservation by TTT is not sufficient?

This bit me the last time someone asked about it, because my first instinct is always to say "if TTT preserves some colimits, then certainly so does T2T^2T2"! But I gather the point is that that's true for a particular shape of colimit that if TTT preserves all such colimits then so does T2T^2T2, but it might happen that TTT preserves a particular colimit diagram but T2T^2T2 doesn't. (That is, if TTT preserves the colimit diagram DDD, then TDTDTD is also a colimit diagram, but TTT might not preserve the colimit diagram TDTDTD so that T2DT^2DT2D is not a colimit diagram.) So in order to find an example of the sort you want, you need a monad TTT that preserves some particular colimit diagram but doesn't preserve all colimits of the same shape, and I would guess that's pretty tricky to come by.
Very nice distinction! I'm sure our team here could find an example.

If I were going to try, the first place I would start looking is to take CCC to be a poset, since colimits in posets and monads on posets are particularly simple to construct "by hand". Maybe there is some small concrete poset that can be drawn by hand on paper, and an idempotent inflationary endofunction (= monad) on it, such that there are two elements that have a join that's preserved by the endofunction but not by its square.
But if the endofunction is idempotent, it’s equal to its square so they can’t do things differently! So posets won’t work…
headdesk
Okay, the second place I would look is... um, I'm not sure.
The trouble is I can't think of any good ways to prove that a functor preserves some particular colimit that don't also prove that it preserves all colimits of the same shape.

I tried coming up with an example of a comonoid AAA in a monoidal closed category with tensor −⊗−-\otimes-−⊗− and internal hom [−,−][-,-][−,−], as well as objects XXX, YYY, such that [A,X]+[A,Y][A, X] + [A, Y][A,X]+[A,Y] is isomorphic to [A,X+Y][A, X + Y][A,X+Y] but [A⊗A,X]+[A⊗A,Y][A \otimes A, X] + [A \otimes A, Y][A⊗A,X]+[A⊗A,Y] is not isomorphic to [A⊗A,X+Y][A \otimes A, X + Y][A⊗A,X+Y], but I did not succeed.
The category cannot be one where the coproduct is actually a biproduct, because otherwise it would be always preserved by [A,−][A, -][A,−].

The idea is to try to categorify something like a ring with elements aaa, bbb and a number kkk such that (a+b)k=ak+bk(a + b)^k = a^k + b^k(a+b)k=ak+bk but (a+b)k2≠ak2+bk2(a + b)^{k^2} \neq a^{k^2} + b^{k^2}(a+b)k2=ak2+bk2 (I haven't come up with a concrete example, sorry)...
Of course if one could find this in a cartesian closed category it would further simplify things because then every object has a canonical comonoid structure.

Screenshot 2025-07-23 at 1.06.46 PM.png
OK, here's a tiny category that, I think, supports a counterexample.

The monad TTT I have in mind is idempotent on {d,e,f,g}\{d,e,f,g\}{d,e,f,g}, being the reflection onto {d,f,g}\{d,f,g\}{d,f,g}. On {a,b,c},\{a,b,c\},{a,b,c}, TTT just "rounds up" to d,e,fd,e,fd,e,f respectively. Therefore TTT is not idempotent but does satisfy T3=T2.T^3=T^2.T3=T2.

With the further point that eee is meant to be a retract of g,g,g, I think everything is now uniquely specified. The unit points northwest at a,b,c,ea,b,c,ea,b,c,e and is the identity at d,f,gd,f,gd,f,g; the only nontrivial multiplication component is the retraction g→eg\to eg→e, which shows the unitality axiom for a monad; and the associativity axiom is vacuous since by the time you're in TTT you're in the idempotent monad we started with on {d,e,f,g}.\{d,e,f,g\}.{d,e,f,g}.

Now, I want to argue that TTT preserves the coproduct b=a+cb=a+cb=a+c but T2T^2T2 does not. The key question is why ggg is not itself the coproduct, and the reason is that the cocone d,f→gd,f\to gd,f→g factors through eee, which means this cocone is fixed by ggg's nontrivial idempotent, which disproves uniqueness in the coproduct property for g.g.g.
eee doesn't have any parallel pairs of maps out, so it's easier to see that it actually is the coproduct, which should finish the proof.
But wait, this isn't a counterexample to Aaron's actual claim, because a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c don't support algebra structures! Maybe it can be spruced up to work...

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

The idea is to try to categorify something like a ring with elements aaa, bbb and a number kkk such that (a+b)k=ak+bk(a + b)^k = a^k + b^k(a+b)k=ak+bk but (a+b)k2≠ak2+bk2(a + b)^{k^2} \neq a^{k^2} + b^{k^2}(a+b)k2=ak2+bk2 (I haven't come up with a concrete example, sorry)...

The smallest example of this that I have found is a=1a = 1a=1, b=3b = 3b=3, and k=4k = 4k=4 in the ring Z/29Z\mathbb{Z}/29\mathbb{Z}Z/29Z.
Here one can check that

  • (a+b)4=44(a + b)^4 = 4^4(a+b)4=44 and a4+b4=1+34a^4 + b^4 = 1 + 3^4a4+b4=1+34 are both 24mod  2924\mod 2924mod29,
  • (a+b)16=416(a + b)^{16} = 4^{16}(a+b)16=416 is 16mod  2916\mod 2916mod29 but a16+b16=1+316a^{16} + b^{16} = 1 + 3^{16}a16+b16=1+316 is 21mod  2921\mod 2921mod29.

Perhaps someone has an idea how to categorify this?

(For the exponents k=2,3k = 2, 3k=2,3 the vanishing of the cross-terms in (a+b)k(a + b)^k(a+b)k always implies the vanishing of the cross-terms in (a+b)k2(a + b)^{k^2}(a+b)k2, so k=4k = 4k=4 is the smallest exponent for which this can work.)

I guess I don't know about any monoidal closed category which has a family of objects (n)(n)(n) indexed by integers mod m such that the internal hom works as exponentiation in Z/mZ\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z}Z/mZ, that is, [(n),(k)][(n), (k)][(n),(k)] is isomorphic to (kn)(k^n)(kn)...

Consider the algebraic theory generated by a 1-ary operation fff and a 3-ary operation ggg with the following laws:

  • f(f(x))=xf(f(x)) = xf(f(x))=x.
  • g(x,x,y)=g(x,y,x)=g(y,x,x)=xg(x,x,y) = g(x,y,x) = g(y,x,x) = xg(x,x,y)=g(x,y,x)=g(y,x,x)=x.
  • g(x,f(x),y)=g(x,y,f(x))=g(y,x,f(x))=yg(x,f(x),y) = g(x,y,f(x)) = g(y,x,f(x)) = yg(x,f(x),y)=g(x,y,f(x))=g(y,x,f(x))=y.

The corresponding monad on Set\mathrm{Set}Set preserves the coproduct 1+11 + 11+1. However, in the category of algebras we have 1+1=11 + 1 = 11+1=1.

Oh, I see, nice! The way I see it is that each element xxx has a dual x∗x^*x∗, and then we have a “ternary interaction”, let's write it [x,y,z][x, y, z][x,y,z], such that

  • if two of the three elements are equal, the interaction returns one of them,
  • if two of the three elements are each other's dual, the interaction returns the third element.

Now, in the free algebra TXTXTX on a set XXX with 1 or 2 elements, in each such ternary interaction, it is always the case that either two elements are equal or two elements are each other's dual, which implies that each expression reduces to a generator or the dual of a generator, so the free algebra is finite.
In particular T{x}={x,x∗}T\{x\} = \{x, x^*\}T{x}={x,x∗} and T{x,y}={x,x∗,y,y∗}T\{x, y\} = \{x, x^*, y, y^*\}T{x,y}={x,x∗,y,y∗}, which implies that T(1+1)T(1 + 1)T(1+1) is isomorphic to T1+T1T1 + T1T1+T1 (as sets).
However, as soon as there are at least 3 elements, there is no way to reduce the expression [x,y,z][x, y, z][x,y,z], and the free algebra is infinite. In particular, T(T1+T1)T(T1 + T1)T(T1+T1) is infinite, while the set TT1+TT1TT1 + TT1TT1+TT1 has 8 elements.
I guess the general “trick” is to find an algebraic theory whose free algebra on XXX is [n]×X[n] \times X[n]×X up to a certain finite cardinality of XXX, and infinite afterwards.

That's right! Sorry I was so terse -- I thought it might be a fun puzzle to figure out why it works, and I'm glad you did.

Another feature that makes it a counterexample: not only is the coproduct preserved by TTT and not TTTTTT, but also it isn't created by the monadic forgetful functor. My first tries at constructing a counterexample based on the "trick" you described failed because the coproduct would end up created anyway.
Cute! You should record this somewhere on the nLab.
Sometimes I forget that you can just... add to the nlab if you've found something cool or interesting

The covariant powerset functor P\mathbb{P}P on Set\mathrm{Set}Set also gives a cute example of a limit that is preserved but not repeatedly preserved by an endofunctor. We have 0×0=00 \times 0 = 00×0=0 and P(0)×P(0)=P(0)=1\mathbb{P}(0) \times \mathbb{P}(0) = \mathbb{P}(0) = 1P(0)×P(0)=P(0)=1 but P(1)×P(1)=4≠P(1)=2\mathbb{P}(1) \times \mathbb{P}(1) = 4 \neq \mathbb{P}(1) = 2P(1)×P(1)=4=P(1)=2. The powerset functor isn't a comonad, though.
